meanings.sent1: She decided to outface her fears and stand up to the bully.
meanings.sent2: The hero had to outface the villain in the final showdown.
meanings.sent3: The little dog tried to outface the big dog by barking loudly.
meanings.sent4: In the face of danger, she outfaced it with unwavering courage.
meanings.sent5: His determination to outface the challenges ahead inspired others.

meanings.definition: To outdo in a staring contest
meanings.sent1: He managed to outface his friend in the intense staring competition.
meanings.sent2: The siblings often outface each other in playful staring matches.
meanings.sent3: The cat tried to outface the mouse in a staring contest, but the mouse blinked first.
meanings.sent4: With a steely gaze, she outfaced her opponent and won the staring contest.
meanings.sent5: The determined child was able to outface the challenge of a staring contest with ease.

meanings.definition: To overcome or intimidate by a bold or confident appearance
meanings.sent1: The confident speaker was able to outface the hecklers in the crowd.
meanings.sent2: The team captain knew how to outface their opponents with a strong presence.
meanings.sent3: The tiny kitten tried to outface the big dog by puffing up its fur.
meanings.sent4: She outfaced her fears with a smile, showing her inner strength.
meanings.sent5: His determined expression was enough to outface any doubts about his abilities.
